sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: You're watching Euronews Tonight. I'm Mariam Zahidi and these are the headlines at this hour.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: After Thursday's euphoria, it was a bump back to planet Earth as EU leaders tackled the cost of living crisis, soaring inflation, energy and food security on the final day of the EU summit.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: The U.S. Supreme Court overturns the landmark judgment Roe versus Wade, meaning U.S. states can ban abortions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: A blow for Ukraine. Troops are forced to retreat from the besieged eastern city of Severodonetsk to avoid being encircled by advancing Russian forces. Here in the Cube we'll take a closer look at a misleading Russian TV report that states that thousands in Belgium do not support Ukraine. Good evening EU leaders reconvened in Brussels today to discuss energy and economy as the continent grapples with soaring inflation and a cost of living crisis. After the celebrations over Ukraine's candidate status on Thursday, heads of states faced tougher talks on the summit's second day. Discussions centered on cutting dependence on Russian fossil fuels with a focus on alternative energy sources. Brussels has accused Moscow of weaponizing energy as Russia tightens its squeeze on gas supplies to EU countries.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: In a joint press conference after the summit, EU chiefs stressed that plans are in place to deal with further energy disruptions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: For more, let's now cross over to Brussels and to our correspondent, Shona Murray.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Shona, good to see you there.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: So, after yesterday's absolute euphoria, it was definitely a bump back to earth, as EU leaders, of course, discussed gas, energy, cost of living. The list was endless. Take it through it. Take us through it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: and sort of moving into today when the EU is able to make that historic decision to give candidate status to Ukraine, to Moldova, to potentially Georgia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: We also had some positive news coming from Bulgaria, which could unblock the way for North Macedonia and Albania.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So very much hope in the air in relation to the future of the EU.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: But then, as you said, today, much more sobering discussions about the future in relation to this war that Russia is imposing on Ukraine and the impact that's having on the EU, in particular for energy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: We have around 12 EU member states that have either been fully or partially cut off from Russian gas.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: We know the impact the sanctions are having on the price of oil.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So there's a really very difficult winter ahead.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Take a listen to President of the European Commission Ursula von der Leyen making that point after the summit this afternoon. Not be a return to cheap fossil fuels I think and therefore alongside temporary and targeted support to vulnerable families and businesses it is essential to help our economies and societies to adapt to the new conditions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: The root cause of our problem is our dependence on fossil fuel, which we must get rid of.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: That's EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen making the point that what needs to happen is targeted temporary measures to deal with the pressures putting on businesses, families, economies in relation to the rising cost of inflation, rising inflation and rising cost of energy. But she also making the point that we can't return to cheap fossil fuels. So the two things have to happen at the same time. The issue is, Marianne, there is no solution that treats all 27 member states. Now, the commission said they will respond by around September with some proposals on the table.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: There's a fear that that might be too late.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Miriam?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Definitely difficult times.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Shona, thanks for being across this jam-packed EU summit.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Thanks so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Well, we're now joined from Kyiv by Olga Stefanyshina.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: She's the Deputy Prime Minister of Ukraine for European Integration. Ms. Stefan Nishina, thanks for joining us on the programme tonight. So this has been a monumental and historical decision for Ukraine and it perhaps goes beyond just symbolism by the EU. It's perhaps a real recognition, would you say, of the value that your country can bring to the EU.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Yes, indeed. The first congratulation we were standing following this decision was the congratulation to EU itself and all 27 leaders.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: This decision has brought really back EU on the global arena and the global agenda.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: It is still recognized by basically the full-scale war started on 24th of February.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: It took a while, but we see that the leadership of global democracy is back on track, whether it comes on sanctions or taking the geopolitical steps.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: In Ukraine, it's, of course, a historical decision. It's the end of the very first demand of Ukrainian people to be part of the European family. We're coming back to where we belong. And this is the first legal solution taken in that regard in 30 years of our independence. So coming back to where you belong, but as you're very well aware of, the path to membership itself is very long and very hard, and you're also fighting this war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: How long do you think it's going to take for Ukraine to meet those obligations for membership?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: As I was saying, we had a long way to go before this decision has taken place, before we submitted the application for membership on the fifth day of war. By that time, we already have 70% of legal compliance with the EU legislation, and we have proven to have a fully operational and capable governance in peaceful time, but also in time of a war. So we would definitely not be lacking capacity. And all the world knows that we are not lacking the persistence and dedication. So of course it should take some time because we need to rebuild our country. We need to restore our economy, we need to end the war and win this war, but as soon as the window of opportunity for Ukraine to become a compatible and strong member of the EU will take place, we will be definitely ready for that. Indeed. And, you know, coming to the war itself, we're now into four months. You've had many wins some losses. Does this decision by the EU perhaps renew your faith and resolve to keep going now. Yes indeed. This was a very inspiring moment to our people. Ninety one per cent of which really support and of which really support and understand how much this decision is important. Of course, this decision will not have immediate effect to end the war or to bring us to the ending of this war, but the historical history of this decision will have a multiplication effect.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And this is an extremely inspiring moment for people, for armed services, for those who have been standing on the revolution of dignity for European future. And this is the first victory we gain by fighting for our freedom, for our democracy, for our values. This is the fight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: We're joined now with the political will of 27 members. And our people know that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: You know that over these four years, we have different statements and different positions from different leaders, like Germany, like Netherlands. Sometimes there was, like, very misguiding states from France. But this has ended yesterday yesterday we have the full unity over making Ukraine back to the family and that makes us understand that it is related to going with us until the very last moment when we win in this war and become the member of European Union there was indeed a sign of unity Olga's definition a deputy prime minister of Ukraine for European integration thank UNION. IT WAS INDEED A SIGN OF UNITY. OLGA STEFANISHINA, DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER OF UKRAINE FOR EUROPEAN INTEGRATION, THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR JOINING US ON THE PROGRAM TONIGHT.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: THANK YOU SO MUCH.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: THANK YOU.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: NOW, ROE V. WADE, THE U.S. SUPREME COURT DECISION WHICH UNDERPINS THE CONSTITUTIONAL RIGHT TO ABORTION IN AMERICA HAS BEEN OVERTURNED.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: THE COURT'S JUSTICES VOTED 6-3 AGAINST THE RIGHT, WITH ALL THREE OF THE JUSTICES APPOINTED in America has been overturned. The court's justices voted six to three against the right, with all three of the justices appointed by former President Donald Trump voting to strike down abortion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: It will now be an issue decided by individual states with about half expected to ban or severely restrict the procedure.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Now, earlier this speaker of the House of U.S. Representatives Nancy Pelosi said abortion will now be a key issue in upcoming congressional elections. While Republicans seek to punish and control women Democrats will keep fighting ferociously to enshrine Roe v. Wade and the law of the land.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: This cruel ruling is outrageous and heart-wrenching, but make no mistake, again, it's all on the ballot in November.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Well, let's now get more from Colin Campbell, who joins us from Washington, D.C.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Colin, good to see you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: So this is a stunning, absolutely stunning decision by the U.S. Supreme Court.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Take us through what's happened.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Yeah, really, this is really stunning, Miriam, because this overrules and overturns a 50-year precedent that was established in 1973 with Roe v. Wade.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And, of course, this leaves a lot of women's pregnancy rights and abortion rights in question, where you already have 13 states that will enact trigger laws within the month that could really change the way that women seek out abortions and the way they receive health care. Of course, this also puts in flux the rest of the nation, which will try to deal with how it deals with pregnancy and abortion rights individually so this is really going to change the landscape in the way that women address their health care their abortion rights and the way that the rest of the land is governed when it comes to pro-life and pro-choice debates well let's pick up on what you're saying there about you know the rights of women and stats say that one in four women in the U.S. will seek an abortion in their lifetime. So what is this then going to mean if you could elaborate. Are we going to perhaps see unfortunately an uptick in unsafe abortions. Yeah it's said that about a quarter of all women will receive an abortion before the age of 45. So they're going to this really going to affect a lot of women nationwide as there are already studies as late as last year. A study coming out of the University of Colorado in Boulder saying that there will be an uptick of about 21 percent of women that will be affected by seeking an abortion that may not be done by a medical facility. And this number could increase 33% for Black American women. So we see already there is a disparate amount of people that will be impacted by this law in America. The CDC also says that there are indications that this could show an uptick and this could result in an uptick in women seeking illegal abortions as well. And then of course we have the laws of what happens when someone does have an abortion that is not legally sanctioned. This could result in years in prison by up to five to 15 years. This would be considered a class B felony meaning that this would mean prison time for women who are convicted of receiving an illegal abortion. A class B felony. So what's the reaction then been across the political divide. I mean this is of course a huge victory for conservatives. But what have leading Democrats been saying about this. Yeah of course Democrats are definitely outraged and they're looking to take this as a political action and of course a talking point and then for people to get activated come this November for midterm elections. They want people to respond to the Supreme Court decision at the polls to vote in people who would definitely be more favorable and more open to the issue of women's health care.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: So, of course, we already heard House Speaker Nancy Pelosi speaking about this.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: We are expecting the president of the United States, Joe Biden, to make a statement about the Supreme Court decision.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But this will definitely be a big decision in November when people head out to vote.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: It will indeed. Colin Campbell, thank you for reporting on that story for Euronews from Washington D.C. Thank you so much. OK well we'll take a short break here but stay with us. There's lots more to come on Euronews tonight including well he might be all the way in Rwanda but UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson is back in the hot seat. Can he hang on? Find out after the break.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Welcome back to the programme. Now, the last Ukrainian forces in the embattled city of Severodonetsk have been ordered to withdraw. This comes as Russian forces inch closer to capturing the neighboring city of Lysyshchank, sparking fears of encirclement. Regional authorities announced this morning that troops in Severodonetsk must fall back to avoid further casualties. They added that 90% of homes had been destroyed by Russian shelling. Around 12,000 civilians are reported to be holed up in the city, but the destruction of three key bridges has thwarted evacuation efforts.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: With up to 20 million tonnes of grain remaining stuck inside water in Ukraine,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: there are fears the world is facing a hunger crisis.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: That's the message coming from Germany, which is hosting a key G7 summit in Bavaria.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But how will leaders respond to the growing catastrophe? Daniel Bellamy has this report.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The world's facing a hunger crisis. That's the message coming from Germany, which is hosting a key G7 summit this weekend. Around 20 million tonnes of grain remain stuck inside Ukraine and food prices have risen sharply. The G7 knows what the problem is, the questions whether they'll commit to feeding the hungriest people on the planet. It is a hunger crisis that is looming before us like a life-threatening wave. Some of the reasons are not new. Regional conflicts, especially in Afghanistan, Taliban rule, droughts, the consequences of the climate crisis and also the aftermath of COVID-19. But it was Russia's war of aggression against Ukraine that turned a wave into a tsunami. The World Food Programme says a record 345 million people have been pushed into extreme hunger. Somalia is facing its worst drought in 40 years and the WFP is now warning that without a massive injection of funding by donor countries, there will be a famine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Well now we go to the UK where British Prime Minister Boris Johnson faces more problems after the chairman of his party, Oliver Dowden, quit following two by-election defeats. In his resignation letter he said we cannot carry on with business as usual. The Conservatives lost Tiverton and Honiton, one of their safe seats to the Liberal Democrats, while in Wakefield the main opposition Labour Party retook the seat that they had lost in 2019. It was the first electoral contest Johnson has faced since he narrowly survived a vote of confidence amongst his own MPs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But for more let's now cross over to our UK reporter Vincent McAvinny. Vinnie good to see you. So this is a massive double body blow for the Conservatives.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But perhaps the biggest part of this story is the scale of the Lib Dem victory. Take us through it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: It is a huge body blow for Boris Johnson because normally by-elections are in large part down to local issues. But it really seems like this is being seen as a referendum on Boris Johnson's leadership. So as you say, the seat in the north, Wakefield, that was expected to go back to the Labour Party.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The Labour Party only lost it at the 2019 general election.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: It was one of their so-called Red Wall heartlands that really flipped on a Brexit vote.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So that very much expected, though if they hadn't have got it back, huge problem for Labour leader Sikir Starmer, but that was safe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The big surprise of the night was the scale of the victory by the Liberal Democrats, traditionally the secondary opposition party here in the UK. They've suffered in recent years after that coalition with the Conservatives between 2010 and 2015, losing the vast majority of their MPs. But they managed to recapture that seat in the South West, which is another battleground for the Conservatives, to recapture that seat in the southwest, which is another battleground for the Conservatives, usually with the lift ends, on the seat that really no one expected to go because it has been Conservative for 99 years. Even in the huge Labour land side of 97, it wasn't flipped.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And this seat had a 25,000 majority. Now, there was potentially a local issue in play. The MP that had been sitting there had been caught in the House of Commons watching pornography on a number of times.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So there was that scandal as well. But really, the scale of the victory, I don't think even the Lib Dems had dreamed of.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And it shows that the Conservatives are now under threat from the two main opposition parties.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Lots of MPs here in the UK, very angry, very worried about their own seats. And the Lib Dems celebrated by unveiling in that seat a big door with the words, show Boris Johnson the door.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Well, let's come to that worry and concern that you talk about. Boris Johnson has said that he will listen to voters, but he's going to keep going. Can he, especially when you have the resignation of his chairman, Oliver Dowden, and also a former Tory leader, Michael Howard, is also now calling for him to go?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: It's a very tricky time for Boris Johnson, particularly given his situation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: He's currently in Rwanda, thousands of miles away, in a meeting of the Commonwealth heads of government.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: He's then going to the G7 in Germany, and then he goes to a NATO meeting in Spain.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So he's effectively out of the country for at least the next eight days, which could see a breaking in the ranks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: We know that he survived that vote of confidence recently. That means there can't be another one for around a year. But Theresa May won a vote of confidence, but then had to resign within six months. We've seen Oliver Dowden, as you say, resign from the cabinet. At the moment, everyone else on the cabinet seems to be holding firm. They've put out messages in support. But on the back benches, a lot of MPs are very worried. And we could start to see some maneuvering, some trying to maybe try and get behind potential candidates who could replace the prime minister. And that message as well from Michael Howard, who, don't forget, was the leader who actually sacked Boris Johnson the first time he got into a shadow cabinet for lying about an extramarital affair.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So someone who has not liked Boris Johnson in the past, but saying very publicly now that he must go.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So a really difficult situation for Boris Johnson.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: He probably wants to get back as soon as possible to try and firm up support, because in his absence, there could be manoeuvres by people that want to try anything possible to get him out.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Thank you so much Vincent McAvony for painting that picture and definitely not a great time for Boris Johnson to be out of the country. Thanks so much Vinnie.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: OK well we'll take a short break here but coming up Sofia is in the cube.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Did 80,000 people in Brussels really march against aid for Ukraine? We'll take a closer look after the break. Welcome back to Euronews tonight. Now, thousands of trade union workers have demonstrated in Brussels this week about the rising cost of living. But there are misleading claims that the protest was instead about Belgium's support for Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Sofia in the Cube has been taking a closer look. Sofia?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Yes, Maryam. Russia's main state TV channel aired this news report about the protest in Belgium.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: The TV presenter introduces the subject by saying that over 80,000 people marched in the capital of Brussels demanding that the country stop spending millions of euros on Ukraine and focus on its own people instead.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: So here in the Cube we decided to fact-check these claims and we found no evidence that support that these protests were spurred by anger against Belgium's stance on the Ukraine war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: However, it is true that in certain videos like this one from this local state TV channel, we did see banners that criticized sanctions against Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And it's also true that Belgium has spent over 77 million euros on aid to Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: But we found that the majority of the demands from the protesters and the unions did not mention Belgium's aid to Ukraine. Instead the main reason for this protest as you can see in this press release was to change the country's law on wages.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Basically this law prevents wages from increasing by a certain percentage every year in order to not impact the profitability of Belgian businesses. But unions say that this is quite unfair due to the rising cost of living and they also mentioned that certain companies have taken advantage of the war in Ukraine. So Maryam this protest of over 80,000 people was mainly about the rising cost of living and this wage law rather than the government's support for Kyiv. That was quite a bizarre story indeed. Thank you, Sophia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Okay, well that's it from myself and the team but we'll leave you with a no comment from Minoka where over 100 riders on horseback are delighting crowds in celebration of the iconic Saint-Jean festival. Thanks for watching UNEWS tonight. Thank you....
